awd_titl_txt: Conference: Developing Skills for Advanced Careers in Biology for NSF Postdoctoral Fellows in the PRFB Broadening Participation 2022 Cohort
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports a workshop for Postdoctoral Research Fellows in Biology, supported by the Broadening Participation of Groups Underrepresented in Biology track. The workshop is designed to serve fellows from the 2022 cohort by providing support for 24 fellows to attend a workshop facilitated by SACNAS (Society for the Advancement of Chicanos/Hispanics and Native Americans in Science). The purpose of the workshop is to provide a forum for promoting best practices and assessment of broadening participation activities, professional and career development, and to catalyze formation of a virtual cohort.

Postdoctoral Fellows conduct research across all fields of biology supported by the Directorate for Biological Sciences. The Fellows in this track also increase participation at the postdoctoral level through training for advanced careers and engagement with other postdoctoral scientists from groups underrepresented in science. The workshop will allow Fellows to exchange ideas and learn from experts about best practices and assessment of activities to broaden participation. To promote professional development, senior scientists will share effective strategies and information for different career paths. The venue for the workshop is 2022 SACNAS – The National Diversity in STEM Conference. The activities will occur in a day-long workshop prior to SACNAS followed by meetings throughout the three-day conference. Common interests and interactions during the workshop will make possible the formation of collaborations that persist as the Fellows disperse to their home research institutions across the US. Overall the workshop will contribute to the national goal of increasing STEM diversity by supporting leadership in broadening participation and the career success of the Fellows, who themselves comprise a diverse group.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
2023 Developing Skills for Advanced Career Workshop Survey Overview

Postdoc participants from the NSF PRFB 2022 Cohort were asked to complete a post event survey. A total of nine core sessions were listed as part of the workshop. These included five about career profiles, two about best practices, a mentor luncheon focused on SMART goals setting and the opportunity to participate in lightening talk sessions to present on their scientific research and broadening participation.

 

Of the sixteen (16) who participated in the workshop, nine (9) participants completed the survey (56% response rate) and seven (7) did not respond to the request to complete the post event survey.

 

Survey Results: Figure 1. Career Profile Sessions

All 9/9 (100%) of the survey respondents indicated that they found all five of the Career Profile Sessions (ranging from 55% to 100%) as very or somewhat useful, with the presentations by Dr. Aman Husbands and Dr. JP Dundore-Arias as receiving the largest percentage of survey respondents indicate their sessions as very useful (89% and 56%, respectively).

 

Survey Results: Figure 2. Best Practices

All 9/9 (100%) of the survey respondents indicated that the “Best Practices: Broadening Participation and Assessment by Dr. Joanna Shisler” session as very or somewhat useful (89% and 11%, respectively).  All 9/9 (100%) of the survey respondents indicated that the “Best Practices: Culturally Sensitive Mentoring Part I & II by Dr. Diana Azurdia” as very useful.

 

Survey Results: Figure 3. Lunch with Mentors

Seventy-eight percent (7/9; 78%) of the survey respondents indicated that the “Goals Working Lunch with Peers & Mentors” was very or somewhat useful (56% and 22%, respectively).

 

Survey Results: Figure 4. Research Presentation Lightning Talks

All 9/9 (100%) of the survey respondents indicated that the opportunity to present their research and broadening participation to their peers and mentors was very or somewhat useful (67% and 33%, respectively).

 

Survey Results: Figure 5 & Figure 6. Workshop Usefulness Overall

One hundred percent (9/9; 100%) of survey respondents indicated that following their attendance at this workshop, they agree or strongly agree that they better understand various career pathways (see Figure 5). Prior to attending this workshop, 78% (7/9) of survey respondents indicated they agree or strongly agree that they understand various career pathways (see Figure 6).

One hundred percent (9/9; 100%) of survey respondents indicated that following their attendance to this workshop, they agree or strongly agree that they better understand broadening participation assessment and implementation (see Figure 5). Prior to attending this workshop, 56% (5/9) of survey respondents indicated they understand broadening participation assessment and implementation (see Figure 6).

One hundred percent (9/9; 100%) of survey respondents indicated that following their attendance to this workshop, they agree or strongly agree that they better understand culturally sensitive mentoring (see Figure 5). Prior to attending this workshop, 56% (5/9) of survey respondents indicated they understand culturally sensitive mentoring (see Figure 6).

 


Last Modified: 11/22/2024
Modified by: Eben W Lindsey

2023 Developing Skills for Advanced Career Workshop Survey Overview


Postdoc participants from the NSF PRFB 2022 Cohort were asked to complete a post event survey. A total of nine core sessions were listed as part of the workshop. These included five about career profiles, two about best practices, a mentor luncheon focused on SMART goals setting and the opportunity to participate in lightening talk sessions to present on their scientific research and broadening participation.





Of the sixteen (16) who participated in the workshop, nine (9) participants completed the survey (56% response rate) and seven (7) did not respond to the request to complete the post event survey.





Survey Results: Figure 1. Career Profile Sessions 


All 9/9 (100%) of the survey respondents indicated that they found all five of the Career Profile Sessions (ranging from 55% to 100%) as very or somewhat useful, with the presentations by Dr. Aman Husbands and Dr. JP Dundore-Arias as receiving the largest percentage of survey respondents indicate their sessions as very useful (89% and 56%, respectively).





Survey Results: Figure 2. Best Practices 


All 9/9 (100%) of the survey respondents indicated that the Best Practices: Broadening Participation and Assessment by Dr. Joanna Shisler session as very or somewhat useful (89% and 11%, respectively). All 9/9 (100%) of the survey respondents indicated that the Best Practices: Culturally Sensitive Mentoring Part I & II by Dr. Diana Azurdia as very useful.





Survey Results: Figure 3. Lunch with Mentors


Seventy-eight percent (7/9; 78%) of the survey respondents indicated that the Goals Working Lunch with Peers & Mentors was very or somewhat useful (56% and 22%, respectively).





Survey Results: Figure 4. Research Presentation Lightning Talks


All 9/9 (100%) of the survey respondents indicated that the opportunity to present their research and broadening participation to their peers and mentors was very or somewhat useful (67% and 33%, respectively).





Survey Results: Figure 5 & Figure 6. Workshop Usefulness Overall


One hundred percent (9/9; 100%) of survey respondents indicated that following their attendance at this workshop, they agree or strongly agree that they better understand various career pathways (see Figure 5). Prior to attending this workshop, 78% (7/9) of survey respondents indicated they agree or strongly agree that they understand various career pathways (see Figure 6).


One hundred percent (9/9; 100%) of survey respondents indicated that following their attendance to this workshop, they agree or strongly agree that they better understand broadening participation assessment and implementation (see Figure 5). Prior to attending this workshop, 56% (5/9) of survey respondents indicated they understand broadening participation assessment and implementation (see Figure 6).


One hundred percent (9/9; 100%) of survey respondents indicated that following their attendance to this workshop, they agree or strongly agree that they better understand culturally sensitive mentoring (see Figure 5). Prior to attending this workshop, 56% (5/9) of survey respondents indicated they understand culturally sensitive mentoring (see Figure 6).
